content: What follows is not a pro-offender comment, nor is it a holier-than-thou comment from here in the UK. Yes, our incarceration rates are lower than those in the US, but they are, I believe, the highest in Western Europe. My comments apply primarily to the UK, as I know more about British than American society. If the number of people in prison is rising, then this is, at least in part, because the number of crimes is increasing. This surely shows that, at some fundamental level, the current system is not working. Reintroduction of the death penalty in the UK would not significantly change this, as the vast majority of people in prison are not there for offences that any civilised society would consider suitable for the death penalty. In these circumstances, is it not reasonable to at least consider alternatives?

content: What follows is not a pro-offender comment, nor is it a holier-than-thou comment from here in the UK. Yes, our incarceration rates are lower than those in the US, but they are, I believe, the highest in Western Europe. My comments apply primarily to the UK, as I know more about British than American society. If the number of people in prison is rising, then this is, at least in part, because the number of crimes is increasing. This surely shows that, at some fundamental level, the current system is not working. Reintroduction of the death penalty in the UK would not significantly change this, as the vast majority of people in prison are not there for offences that any civilised society would consider suitable for the death penalty. In these circumstances, is it not reasonable to at least consider alternatives?
